tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

Possible meanings are 1) "song people sang while going up to Jerusalem for a celebration" or 2) "song people sang while going up the steps into the temple" or 3) "song whose words are like steps." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:120:001|120:1]]

tn.ref: Jerusalem, our feet are standing within your gates!
tn.text: The writer briefly stops speaking to his audience and speaks directly to the city of Jerusalem. Jerusalem is spoken to as if it was a person who could hear the writer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
Here "feet" refers to the whole person. AT: "we are standing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "gates" refers to the city. AT: "inside you, Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "name" refers to Yahweh himself. AT: "Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "house" refers to the descendants of David. AT: "the descendants of David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: May those who love you have peace ... peace within your fortresses
tn.text: This section states the content of the prayer that the writer wants his audience to pray. He asks them to speak directly to the city of Jerusalem, as if the city was a person who could hear them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: May there be peace within ... may they have peace within
tn.text: These two phrases have the same meanings and are used together to strengthen each other. AT: "May the people in Jerusalem live in peace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: within the walls that defend you ... within your fortresses
tn.text: Here Jerusalem is referred to by the fortress walls that protects it. The terms "walls" and "fortress" refer to the same thing. AT: "within Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

In this section, the writer speaks directly to the city of Jerusalem, as if the city was a person who could hear them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: May there be peace within you
tn.text: "I pray that the people in you will live in peace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The abstract noun "good" can be stated as an action. AT: "desire that people treat you well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
